title: Body Fat Calculator
description: Calculate your body fat percentage using the U.S. Navy method. Enter your measurements to find your body fat percentage, lean body mass, and body composition category.

meta.title: Free Body Fat Calculator - Navy Method Body Fat Percentage [2026]
meta.description: Calculate your body fat percentage with our free Navy method calculator. Get accurate estimates of body fat, lean mass, and fitness category for men and women.
meta.keywords: body fat calculator, body fat percentage, navy method, body composition, lean body mass, fat mass calculator, body fat categories, fitness calculator

inputs.hipNote: Required for women only. Measure at the widest point.

results.title: Your Body Fat Results
results.inRange: You are within the fitness range

validation.agePositive: Age must be a positive number
validation.ageTooLow: This calculator is designed for adults (18+)
validation.heightPositive: Height must be a positive number
validation.heightTooLow: Height must be at least 100 cm (39 in)
validation.weightPositive: Weight must be a positive number
validation.weightTooLow: Weight must be at least 30 kg (66 lbs)
validation.neckPositive: Neck circumference must be a positive number
validation.neckTooLow: Neck circumference must be at least 20 cm (8 in)
validation.neckTooHigh: Please enter a valid neck circumference
validation.waistPositive: Waist circumference must be a positive number
validation.waistTooLow: Waist circumference must be at least 40 cm (16 in)
validation.waistTooHigh: Please enter a valid waist circumference
validation.hipRequired: Hip circumference is required for women
validation.hipPositive: Hip circumference must be a positive number
validation.hipTooLow: Hip circumference must be at least 50 cm (20 in)
validation.hipTooHigh: Please enter a valid hip circumference
validation.waistMustBeGreaterThanNeck: Waist must be larger than neck for accurate calculation

disclaimer.text: This body fat calculator uses the U.S. Navy method and provides estimates only. Results may vary based on measurement accuracy and individual body composition. For precise body fat assessment, consider DEXA scans or professional hydrostatic weighing.
disclaimer.note: Body fat percentage is just one indicator of health. Athletes, bodybuilders, and individuals with high muscle mass may see different results. Always consult healthcare professionals for personalized advice.

seo.whatIsContent: Body fat percentage is the proportion of your total body weight that consists of fat tissue. It's a more accurate measure of fitness than weight alone because it accounts for the difference between fat mass and lean mass (muscle, bone, organs, and water). Understanding your body fat percentage can help you set realistic fitness goals and track your progress more effectively than the scale alone.
seo.howToCalculateContent: This calculator uses the U.S. Navy method developed by Hodgdon and Beckett in 1984. It estimates body fat percentage using circumference measurements of the neck, waist, and hips (for women). The formulas use logarithmic calculations based on these measurements and height.
seo.howToCalculateFormulaMen: Men: BF% = 86.010 x log10(waist - neck) - 70.041 x log10(height) + 36.76
seo.howToCalculateFormulaWomen: Women: BF% = 163.205 x log10(waist + hip - neck) - 97.684 x log10(height) - 78.387
seo.categoryDescEssentialMen: Minimum fat needed for basic health functions. This level is typically seen only in elite athletes and bodybuilders during competition.
seo.categoryDescAthleticMen: Common among athletes and those with high physical conditioning. Visible muscle definition and vascularity.
seo.categoryDescFitnessMen: Ideal range for most men seeking a fit, healthy appearance. Some muscle definition visible.
seo.categoryDescAcceptableMen: Healthy range for average men. May have minimal muscle definition.
seo.categoryDescObeseMen: Increased health risks including heart disease, diabetes, and metabolic disorders.
seo.categoryDescEssentialWomen: Minimum fat needed for hormonal function and reproductive health. Only seen in elite female athletes.
seo.categoryDescAthleticWomen: Common among female athletes. Very lean with visible muscle tone.
seo.categoryDescFitnessWomen: Ideal range for most women seeking a fit appearance. Healthy and sustainable.
seo.categoryDescAcceptableWomen: Healthy range for average women. Normal body composition.
seo.categoryDescObeseWomen: Increased health risks including hormonal imbalances, heart disease, and diabetes.
seo.howToMeasureStep1: Neck: Measure below the larynx (Adam's apple) with the tape slightly sloping downward to the front. Keep the tape snug but not tight.
seo.howToMeasureStep2: Waist (Men): Measure at the navel level horizontally. Stand relaxed and don't suck in your stomach.
seo.howToMeasureStep3: Waist (Women): Measure at the narrowest point of your natural waist, typically just above the belly button.
seo.howToMeasureStep4: Hips (Women only): Measure at the widest point of your hips and buttocks with feet together.
seo.howToMeasureStep5: Take measurements in the morning before eating, after using the restroom. Measure directly on skin for best accuracy.
seo.limitation1: Estimates may be less accurate for very muscular individuals or those with unusual body proportions
seo.limitation2: Results can vary by 3-4% compared to more precise methods like DEXA or hydrostatic weighing
seo.limitation3: Measurement accuracy depends on proper technique and consistent placement
seo.limitation4: May not account for individual variations in fat distribution
seo.limitation5: Not suitable for children, pregnant women, or individuals with certain medical conditions
seo.howToUseStep1: Select your gender - this determines which formula is used and whether hip measurement is needed
seo.howToUseStep2: Enter your age (must be 18 or older)
seo.howToUseStep3: Choose your preferred unit system (metric or imperial) and enter your height and weight
seo.howToUseStep4: Take and enter your circumference measurements (neck, waist, and hips for women)
seo.howToUseStep5: View your results including body fat percentage, category, and recommended targets
seo.tip1: Create a moderate caloric deficit through a combination of diet and exercise
seo.tip2: Include strength training to preserve muscle mass while losing fat
seo.tip3: Prioritize protein intake (0.7-1g per pound of body weight) to support muscle retention
seo.tip4: Get adequate sleep (7-9 hours) as poor sleep can hinder fat loss
seo.tip5: Be patient - aim for 0.5-1% body fat loss per month for sustainable results
seo.faq1Question: How accurate is the Navy body fat calculator?
seo.faq1Answer: The U.S. Navy method is generally accurate within 3-4% of more precise methods like DEXA scans. While not perfect, it provides a good estimate for tracking changes over time. For the most accurate results, take measurements consistently at the same time of day and follow proper measurement techniques.
seo.faq2Question: What is a healthy body fat percentage?
seo.faq2Answer: Healthy body fat ranges differ by gender. For men, 14-24% is considered acceptable to fit, with 6-13% being athletic. For women, 21-31% is acceptable to fit, with 14-20% being athletic. Essential fat levels (2-5% for men, 10-13% for women) should not be maintained long-term.
seo.faq3Question: Why is body fat percentage better than BMI?
seo.faq3Answer: Body fat percentage directly measures fat tissue, while BMI only considers height and weight. This means muscular individuals may have a high BMI but healthy body fat, while those with little muscle could have normal BMI but high body fat (often called 'skinny fat'). Body fat percentage gives a more complete picture of body composition.
seo.faq4Question: Can I lose fat without losing muscle?
seo.faq4Answer: Yes! To preserve muscle while losing fat: maintain a moderate caloric deficit (not too extreme), eat adequate protein (0.7-1g per pound of body weight), perform resistance training, and ensure proper recovery. Rapid weight loss typically results in significant muscle loss.
seo.faq5Question: How often should I measure body fat?
seo.faq5Answer: Measure body fat every 2-4 weeks rather than daily. Body composition changes slowly, and daily measurements can be misleading due to water retention and other factors. Track trends over time rather than focusing on individual measurements.
seo.faq6Question: Why do women have higher essential fat?
seo.faq6Answer: Women require higher essential fat (10-13% vs 2-5% for men) due to reproductive functions, hormonal regulation, and breast tissue. Very low body fat in women can lead to amenorrhea (loss of menstruation), bone density loss, and other health issues.
seo.faq7Question: Is it possible to have too little body fat?
seo.faq7Answer: Yes. Essential fat is required for normal physiological function. Going below essential levels can cause hormonal disruption, weakened immunity, decreased athletic performance, organ damage, and in severe cases, death. Extremely low body fat should only be achieved temporarily for competitions under professional guidance.
seo.faq8Question: Why does the formula need hip measurement for women?
seo.faq8Answer: Women store fat differently than men, with more fat typically deposited around the hips and thighs (gynoid pattern) compared to men's abdominal storage (android pattern). Including hip circumference improves accuracy by accounting for these sex-specific fat distribution patterns.
